entry.title: Streamlining User Management in SAP Ariba Category Management with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
This blog post highlights an important update in user management within SAP Ariba Category Management, released in May 2025. The new, centralized approach minimizes manual intervention and boosts security, simplifying processes and enhancing efficiency. For customers with SAP Ariba Category Management tenants provisioned after May 16, 2025, no action is required. These tenants automatically follow the user group-based model.  SAP Ariba Category Management tenants provisioned before May 16, 2025 require manual adjustments. 

This post outlines the necessary steps to transition from role-based assignments to a user group-based model and guides you through the transition process.

 

What‚Äôs Changed

With the May 2025 release we provided a significant improvement in the way user management is handled within SAP Ariba Category Management. You can now assign predefined, category management-specific user groups directly from the Identity Authentication service in SAP Cloud Identity Services to SAP Ariba Category Management users (Figure 1).

Figure 1: User groups for SAP Ariba Category Management

In the past, user data had to be replicated from the Identity Authentication service tenant to SAP Ariba Category Management. This involved scheduling regular synchronization jobs and assigning roles through separate user interfaces. Now, users who need access to SAP Ariba Category Management are assigned predefined user groups directly within the Identity Authentication service tenant in SAP Cloud Identity Services. 

Note: Setting up a replication job is still required for integration with the embedded SAP Analytics Cloud and the intelligent opportunity analyzer. For more information, see Replicating Users from Identity Authentication Service to SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Key Benefits

  • You can assign user groups directly within SAP Cloud Identity Services without using the SAP BTP cockpit's application configuration UI. This ensures all user management activities are centralized in one place.
  • Previously, syncing user data required a replication job between Identity Authentication and SAP Ariba Category Management. With this update, user replication for SAP Ariba Category Management is no longer needed, streamlining the process further.

Note: Setting up a replication job is still required for integration with the embedded SAP Analytics Cloud and the intelligent opportunity analyzer. For more information, see Replicating Users from Identity Authentication Service to SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Steps for Transitioning Tenants Provisioned before May 16, 2025

If you provisioned SAP Ariba Category Management before the May 2025 release, you need to make some manual adjustments to transition to the new model. The concrete steps you need to follow depend on whether your SAP Ariba Category Management tenants were provisioned in an SAP-managed SAP BTP account, following the simplified provisioning approach via SAP for Me, or whether your tenants were manually provisioned in a customer-managed SAP BTP account.

 

SAP-Managed Setup (Simplified Provisioning)

These steps are relevant for tenants provisioned after August 16, 2024 and before May 16, 2025.

Step 1: Assign the predefined category management-specific user groups to SAP Ariba Category Management users in SAP Cloud Identity Services (Figure 2).

Figure 2: Assigning user groups to users in SAP Cloud Identity Services

For more information, see the configuration guide at Assigning Category Management User Groups to Users on SAP Cloud Identity Services.

Step 2: In the SAP BTP cockpit, remove individual users assigned directly to role collections (Figure 3).

Figure 3: Removing role collections from users in SAP BTP Cockpit

For more information, see the configuration guide at Delete Users from Role Collections.

Step 3: Delete the target system created for SAP Ariba Category Management, or alternatively, remove the SAP Ariba Category Management target system from the source system on the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant.

Figure 4: Deleting the target system from SAP Cloud Identity Services

For more information, see configuration guide at Delete Target System.

 

Customer-Managed Setup (Manual Provisioning)

These steps are relevant for tenants provisioned before August 16, 2024.

Step 1: Create category management-specific user groups in SAP Cloud Identity Services (Figure 5), using the user group names and display names described in the configuration guide. For more information, see Creating User Groups for Category Management Users.

Figure 5: Creating user groups for SAP Ariba Category Management

Step 2: Assign the predefined category management-specific user groups to SAP Ariba Category Management users in SAP Cloud Identity Services (Figure 2). For more information, see Assigning Category Management User Groups to Users on SAP Cloud Identity Services.

Step 3: Map the created user groups to the corresponding role collections in the SAP Ariba Category Management subaccount on SAP BTP (Figure 6).

Figure 6: Mapping role collections to user groups

For more information, see Mapping User Groups to Role Collections.

Step 4: Remove individual users assigned directly to role collections in the SAP BTP cockpit (Figure 3). For more information, see Delete Users from Role Collections.

Step 5: Delete the target system created for SAP Ariba Category Management, or alternatively, remove the SAP Ariba Category Management target system from the source system on the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant (Figure 4). For  more information, see Delete Target System.

 

Conclusion

Transitioning to a user group-based access model in SAP Ariba Category Management is pivotal to a more streamlined, secure, and efficient user management process. For customers with existing tenants, it's crucial to migrate to the new process, while those with new tenants will see immediate benefits from automatic configurations.

For detailed steps and further guidance, explore the following resources in the configuration guide for SAP Ariba Category Management on SAP Help Portal:

  • User Management
  • Assigning Category Management User Groups to Users on SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Migration of SAP Ariba Category Management Tenants to User Group-Based Access

entry.title: What puts AI Adoption at Risk and How to Avoid the Pitfalls
entry.content:
(Series: Foundations for AI Success in SAP Landscapes) 

If your organization is eager to ‚Äúswitch on AI‚Äù in‚ÄØSAP, you‚Äôre not alone. But here‚Äôs the pattern we keep seeing: teams light up AI features in one‚ÄØline-of-business (LoB)‚ÄØapp, it looks promising, and then everything stalls‚Äîor breaks‚Äîwhen they try to add the next LoB. 

This post explains why these activations are at stake, what ‚Äúgood‚Äù looks like for a unified agent experience with‚ÄØJoule, and how to get ready the right way. The goal: one Joule that works across your‚ÄØSAP‚ÄØlandscape‚Äîwithout rework,‚ÄØidentity‚ÄØheadaches, or dead ends‚Äîso users never have to think about which system is behind the task. 

Why 

End users expect a single assistant that ‚Äújust knows‚Äù where to go to answer a question or complete a task‚Äîcreate a leave request, initiate a purchase order, summarize a case. But activation often happens app by app: one Joule for‚ÄØSuccessFactors, another for‚ÄØS/4HANA, another for Signavio. That fragmentation shows up fast: 

  • The AI can‚Äôt act in the user‚Äôs name across systems, so it can‚Äôt complete high-value actions. 
  • Agents would not be able to perform system to system interaction in the context of a real identity. 
  • Each new‚ÄØLoB‚ÄØreintroduces the same‚ÄØidentity‚ÄØand provisioning challenges with system-specific workarounds. 

The one prerequisite that makes or breaks activation: identity‚ÄØ 

Principal propagation‚Äîthe AI acting in the user‚Äôs own identity with the right authorizations and audit trail‚Äîis the critical path. It requires your‚ÄØBTP‚ÄØsubaccount and each backend system (S/4HANA,‚ÄØSuccessFactors,‚ÄØAriba,‚ÄØConcur, etc.) to trust the same‚ÄØSAP Cloud Identity Services ‚Äì Identity Authentication Service (IAS), with consistent provisioning and a stable‚ÄØGlobal User ID‚ÄØthat maps the same person across systems. With mixed identity providers or uncoordinated tenants, calls fail or fall back to technical users, which won‚Äôt satisfy‚ÄØsecurity‚ÄØor‚ÄØaudit‚ÄØrequirements. 

SAP Build Work Zone‚ÄØhelps Joule understand and route capabilities to the right system‚Äîthink of Work Zone as the registry that sends ‚Äúcreate leave request‚Äù to‚ÄØSuccessFactors‚ÄØor ‚Äúcreate purchase order‚Äù to‚ÄØS/4HANA. If Work Zone isn‚Äôt set up with the right trust and‚ÄØdestinations, routing won‚Äôt be reliable and end-to-end scenarios won‚Äôt complete. 

Common activation failure patterns 

  • Fragmented identity and user matching: Multiple‚ÄØCloud Identity Services tenants, no central trust, and no‚ÄØGlobal User ID‚ÄØundermine principal propagation. 
  • Missing Work Zone foundation: Work Zone not provisioned, trusted, or populated with‚ÄØdestinations, leaving Joule without a reliable navigation context. 
  • Per-LOB BTP sprawl: Uncoordinated‚ÄØsubaccounts,‚ÄØentitlements,‚ÄØrole collections, and destinations block a unified agent experience. 
  • Authorization blind spots: Backend roles aren‚Äôt synchronized, so the assistant won‚Äôt act. 
  • ‚ÄúFlip the switch‚Äù mindset: Assuming production activation without assessment,‚ÄØtest‚ÄØruns, or guardrails leads to early wins that collapse when you add the second‚ÄØLoB. 

The goal: a unified Joule by design 

  • One identity plane: A designated‚ÄØSAP Cloud Identity Services‚ÄØtenant trusted by‚ÄØBTP‚ÄØand your SAP apps, with end-to-end‚ÄØprincipal propagation‚ÄØand a consistent‚ÄØGlobal User ID. 
  • Work Zone as the capability map: Trusted‚ÄØSAP Build Work Zone‚ÄØwith established‚ÄØdestinations‚ÄØso Joule can route to the right backend. 
  • A coherent BTP footprint: Clear‚ÄØsubaccount‚ÄØstrategy, correct‚ÄØentitlements,‚ÄØJoule booster‚ÄØexecuted and validated, connectivity established, and‚ÄØrole collections‚ÄØaligned. 
  • Role and authorization awareness: Backend‚ÄØauthorizations‚ÄØsynchronized so Joule knows what each user can do and logs actions under that user‚Äôs identity. 

This blog describes the technical prerequisites‚Äîthe SAP IAM Reference Architecture for SAP Business AI‚Äîin detail. 

The SAP Joule Readiness Service guides you to avoid these pitfalls and get to a unified assistant that ‚Äújust works‚Äù  

Who it‚Äôs for 

  • Customers aiming to enable‚ÄØJoule‚ÄØin‚ÄØSAP Cloud LoB‚ÄØsolutions‚Äîsuch as‚ÄØSuccessFactors‚ÄØor‚ÄØCloud ERP‚Äîwho face challenges meeting prerequisites, especially in‚ÄØidentity lifecycle‚ÄØand‚ÄØauthentication management (IAM). 

How the service helps 

  • Establishes a consistent, unified‚ÄØSAP Cloud Identity Services infrastructure 
  • Develops a‚ÄØGlobal User ID‚ÄØconcept so the same person is recognized across systems 
  • Resolves hurdles related to‚ÄØSAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS/IPS) 
  • Integrates with your existing authentication processes (for example,‚ÄØMicrosoft Entra ID) 
  • Hands-on analysis of your current setup (identity‚ÄØlandscape, provisioning, authentication flows) 
  • Hands-on support to understand prerequisites, plan activities, implement them in your‚ÄØtest landscape, and define follow-up recommendations 

Delivery approach and scope 

  • An initial workshop to discover the technical prerequisites for a Unified SAP Joule experience and explain the SAP IAM Reference Architecture 
  • Multiple iterations of system analysis workshops to identify gaps in‚ÄØtenant setup, user management, authentication and‚ÄØauthorization setup for SAP Joule activation in the test landscape, tailored for one LoB scenario 
  • Wrap-up presentation with identified gaps, tailored best practices for‚ÄØproduction, and pointers to additional services as needed 

How to book 

Use this booking link and request for "Cloud Identity Service for SAP Joule & SAP Business AI (IAS, IPS)", this service is‚ÄØfree of charge.

entry.title: The Power of One: How Unified SAP Joule Boosts AI Adoption (a technical sight)
entry.content:
Short read. Big pictures.

What is ‚ÄòUnified SAP Joule‚Äô? One Joule for all SAP solutions, independent of the underlying tech stacks. (End users know ‚ÄòSAP,‚Äô not SFSF/S4/BS, etc.)

Why unify? Better user acceptance ‚Üí better adoption. If users don‚Äôt accept it, they won‚Äôt adopt it.

How to get there? Use the SAP IAM Reference Architecture for SAP Joule as the backbone, following down below:

 

1) Overview

Everything SAP‚Äëlabeled shows up to the corporate IAM/IdP as SAP Cloud Identity (SCI). Inside the SAP domain, identities & authorizations are unified so the landscape can be SAP‚Äëmanaged later. User management, role/group assignment, and authentication all go through SAP Cloud Identity Services.

‚ÄÉ

2) Common Data Model (CDM)

At design time ‚Äì when activating SAP Joule, each business solution (e.g., S/4HANA) exposes its Joule capabilities via CDM. Joule functions map to business roles; CDM content is deployed to SAP Build Work Zone (WZ); Roles defined in CDM appear as roles in Content Manager.
E.g. S4 HANA Capability <-> S/4 HANA Business Role <-> CDM role <-> Role in WZ <-> Capability in WZ.
Given that, SAP Joule knows at DT what authorizations a user need for which capability.

 

3) Sync of Authorizations

Roles/groups and identity assignments from business solution (S/4 HANA, SuccessFactors, ‚Ä¶) synchronize into Work Zone. Synchronizing groups and assignments into SCI are optional today and may become required if WZ polls SCI. Third‚Äëparty IAM can assign groups to users via SCI; Work Zone‚Äôs user store is independent of XSUAA.

 

4) Sync of Identities

Identities flow through SCIM to your identity management, centrally governed across SAP. The Global Unique User Identifier is synchronized from SCI into the business solutions.

 

5) Authentication Flow

All authentication goes through SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS), enabling principal propagation behind the scenes (later more). This is the basis for Unified SAP Joule and prepares the path for SAP‚Äëmanaged connectivity when new services are subscribed.

 

6) Example: End‚Äëto‚ÄëEnd Authentication

  1. User opens Joule.
  2. Joule asks IAS to authenticate user; Optional: IAS forwards authentication to Corporate IdP and enriches token with IAS information (GUUID) after authentication (identity federation).
  3. User is authenticated to use Joule while Joule knows, which capabilities the user is allowed to use.
  4. User is calling a Joule capability (e.g. Create leave request).
  5. Joule asks IAS for a token for this specific identity for the business solution of the capability to be called.
  6. IAS is handing out the token.
  7. Joule can authenticate as the user to the business solution (principal propagation).
  8. Joule calling the function module inside the business solution in the name of the user.

This illustrates the importance for all solutions and the BTP within this scenario to trust the same authentication instance (IAS).

 

7) 3rd‚ÄëParty Identity Management (where it fits)

  • Identity sources: SFSF (internals), Fieldglass (externals), or AD.
  • Synchronization of users between SFSF and SCI.
  • GUUID is written back to SFSF.
  • Groups originate in SaaS solutions and show as SCI groups can sync to 3rd-party IAM.
  • S/4 HANA roles can sync to 3rd‚Äëparty IAM.
  • Management split:
    • BTP & SaaS via SCI.
    • S/4 HANA via IAM directly plus GUUID provisioning:
      • IAM reads from SCI and provisions to S/4 HANA, or
      • SCI reads from S/4 HANA and writes back UserID+GUUID only;
      • Both option align with the reference architecture.

 

Final thought

Unify identity and auth once ‚Üí unlock Joule everywhere. Less friction. More adoption. Happier users. üéØ

Public source for architectural drawings: IAM Reference Architecture for SAP Joule in Architecture Center

entry.title: Identity and Access Management with Microsoft Entra, Part III: SuccessFactors and Role Provisioning
entry.content:
Part II of this blog series took a technical deep-dive into a hybrid scenario for managing identities and their access across SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and S/4HANA on-premise. Part III enhances the scenario by introducing SAP SuccessFactors (SF) as the source for employee and user data, and leverages the new capabilities in Entra for SCIM-based provisioning to SAP Cloud Identity Service (CIS) supporting groups to streamline end-to-end role assignments in the connected SAP ABAP backend.

Scenario Overview

Part III introduces substantial changes and enhancements to the scenario in part II:

  • Microsoft Entra and Active Directory (AD) were the primary and authoritative systems (aka "source of authority", SOA) for identity data in part II. For many organizations, however, the trusted SOA for identities is a Human Resource Information System (HRIS) such as SAP SuccessFactors (SF), which will be added to the scenario in this part, and where new employees are now onboarded.
  • Identity creation, updates, and deprovisioning are now driven by HR events (e.g., hiring, role changes, terminations) from SF. AD and Entra become downstream provisioning targets in this scenario. Because users require access to SAP from SAP GUI on their corporate AD domain-joined workstation using Kerberos/SNC-based single sign-on (SSO, see part II), the solution architecture in this scenario integrates SF with the SAP SuccessFactors to Active Directory user provisioning connector from the Microsoft Entra App Gallery. This pre-built, cloud-based solution supports inbound- or HR-driven provisioning of new employees from SF to AD through Entra. New users provisioned to AD by this connector will be synchronized to Entra with the existing setup of the Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync Provisioning Agent from part II of this blog series that runs on the Domain Controller (DC) in our fictitious company BestRun's corporate network.
  • Part II focused on the automation of provisioning the user's identity data. The user's authorization in the SAP backend (we used role SAP_BC_ABAP_DEVELOPER_5 as an example) was still managed manually by assigning the user to the equally named group "SAP_BC_ABAP_DEVELOPER_5" in the CIS tenant (see step 10.20 in part II). Also the group in CIS had to be created manually in the previous part of the scenario (see steps 9.17-9.19). This approach may work for a few backend authorizations, but won't scale for a larger number of connected systems and applications with complex authorization models. A key objective in this scenario is to fully automate end-to-end provisioning and deprovisioning of the user's authorizations, which includes the synchronization of backend roles and their corresponding groups in CIS and Entra, as well as the memberships of users to these groups, that ultimately assigns them to the backend roles. The updated version of the SAP CIS connector from the Microsoft Entra App Galley now enables automated provisioning of groups and their entitlements as memberships from Entra to CIS. This new feature in the SCIM (System for Cross-domain Identity Management, IETF RFCs 7642, 7643 and 7644)-compliant outbound provisioning connector in Entra streamlines the end-to-end lifecycle management for authorizations in the scenario. By assigning the new user to a group representing the PFCG role in the SAP ABAP system, this group and the user's membership are now also automatically provisioned to CIS, and from there to the backend system. Similar to part II, the group in Entra and CIS is mapped to the PFCG role by using the same name.

Figure 1 illustrates the SOA for the IAM entities in the scenario:

Figure 1

 

Although SOA for identity data moves to SF, the connected SAP system remains the authority for the definition of the roles that can be assigned in the scenario. Managing the actual assignment of users to these roles through access packages and approval workflows remains the responsibility of Entra ID Governance. With no single SOA for users, groups and roles centralized at one place in the system landscape, figure 1 shows the updated and newly introduced system components based on the existing setup from part II, and illustrates the steps of the provisioning flow for a new onboarded employee requesting access to a role in the corporate SAP system:

 

Figure 2

 

 

 

  1. CIS is responsible to integrate the connected SAP systems following this reference architecture. It synchronizes the role from the backend (SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO in this scenario) with the SAP Application Server ABAP connector configured as a Source System in BestRun's CIS tenant Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) which results in creating a group with the same name in the tenant's local directory. Connectivity from CIS to the SAP system on-premises remains unchanged from part II and is established via the connectivity service in BTP and the SAP Cloud Connector deployed in the corporate network.
  2. CIS also takes care for creating the group in Entra by provisioning it with the Entra ID connector configured as a target system in the CIS tenant. This connector uses the Microsoft Graph API to manage groups in Entra.
  3. The HR admin adds a new employee record in SF for the user in the sceanrio, Linda Larson. 
  4. The SAP SuccessFactors to Active Directory user provisioning connector picks up the new employee record by calling the SF Employee Central OData API endpoints to query for new or updated data.
  5. The connector then provisions a user account for the new employee Linda in BestRun's corporate AD via Entra Cloud Sync and the Entra Provisioning Agent on the DC.
  6. With Entra Cloud Sync configured in part II to synchronize AD with the Entra tenant, the new account in the corporate AD is also provisioned to BestRun's Entra ID tenant.
  7. Linda starts a request for the SAP EPM access package with the MyAccess portal. For this initial login to Entra, Linda can use the self-service password reset (SSPR) feature in Entra to set her new Entra user account's password. With password writeback enabled in Entra Cloud Sync and SSPR to use password writeback, Linda's initial password reset or any future changes of her password are synchronized back to BestRun's on-premises AD as well. By completing the request, Linda is assigned to the access package resources, and becomes a member in the SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO group in Entra. To keep things simple, the access package policy requires no approval steps in this scenario.
  8. The SAP CIS connector enterprise app is configured to perform all operations (create/update/delete) on new or existing user objects, but to skip creation on groups. Otherwise, Entra would try to create the same group again in CIS that has already been created in step 1, which would result in a naming conflict. Instead, it creates a new user account for Linda in CIS, but only updates her membership to the SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO group in BestRun's CIS tenant.
    In addition to the new support for groups in the new version of the SAP CIS connector, authentication to CIS no longer uses basic authentication that sends static credentials with every request. Instead, short‚Äëlived tokens with scoped, limited privileges using the OAuth 2.0 client credentials grant flow enhance security over basic authentication.
  9. Provisioning to the SAP backend with the already existing SAP Application Server ABAP connector configured as a Target System in IPS starts by reading the new user and her group membership from the CIS tenant's local directory, and creating the new user in SAP as well as assigning this user to the corresponding SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO role.
  10. Finally, Linda can login to BestRun's corporate AD from her workstation, obtains a Kerberos token from the DC, and uses it to securely single sign-on to the backend from SAP GUI and the SAP Secure Login Client. This requires mapping of her user principal name (UPN) in AD to her SAP user, which has already been configured in the mappings of the SAP CIS connector in Entra (see step 6.18 in part II) and the transformation of the SAP Application Server ABAP target system in IPS (see step 9.12 in part II).
